bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, January 25, 1925

div1.p: [Carter] discusses mosquito breeding in containers and wells, and the use of quinine injections.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William E. Deeks, January 25, 1925
div1.opener:
Miscl
Deeks
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
, D. C.,
January 25, 1925.
Dr. W. E. Deeks, General Manager,
Medical Department,
United Fruit Company,
17 Battery Place,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Deeks:
div1.p:
I put off answering your letter of January 16th., until I could
hear from Griffitts and LePrince about the breeding of Anopheles in
wells& artificial containers reported at the New Orleans meeting and am en-
closing their answers, which I will ask you to kindly return to me.

You are right: in the deep sub-cutaneous use of quinine. I
have not seen trouble from that.

With regard to the ampules: At Santo Tomas we had no necro-
sis or abcess in something over 200 or 250 injections, using the
French ampules put up for this purpose. Many of the injections
were given by the nurses, who were not as skilled in such matters
as is the well-trained American nurse.

This letter is written, however, practically in re Anopheles
breeding in wells, which I doubted was of sanitary importance in
the U. S. It is, however--Kligler tells me--in Palestine. The
wells there, however, are really underground cisterns and the spe-
cies breeding is bifurcatus, which has not been reported, I think,
as occurring in the Americas.

I will be glad to get a copy of your paper when it is printed--
printed
-2-
a half dozen, if you have them, as there are some to whom I would
like to send them.

With best wishes to you and yours, in which Laura, who is
writing this, joins
